3.84.text: - So we know that starting a company

6.98.text: or being involved with a start-up

8.78.text: is full of surprises and often

11.33.text: pits that you fall into, as well as really fabulous highs.

16.41.text: Have there been already some surprises

19.57.text: that you could share with us?

21.29.text: Obviously you started with the idea

23.00.text: that okay, this is gonna be fabulous and great,

25.01.text: but what happened that might have

28.47.text: Cody, do you want to start?

30.03.text: - Yeah, for us, we're surprised that,

31.81.text: so we built a training tool for professional athletes

33.93.text: to use VR to train, and we're always surprised

36.51.text: that coaches don't want to use the tool.

38.80.text: I think the biggest surprise for me is

41.17.text: how important sales is to our cycle,

43.62.text: is to actually try to sell this tool,

46.10.text: because to us we are a company of athletes

48.92.text: and sports-minded folk, but the sales process

52.88.text: is so important to the industry,

55.02.text: and I think the biggest surprise was just

56.97.text: how hard we need to work at that.

59.71.text: So instead of proving it as a tool,

61.82.text: it's always about pitching it to kind of,

63.83.text: how do they use it in a way that is effective for them,

69.10.text: and how do we pitch it to them as something that's gonna be

71.52.text: non-invasive to their current coaching philosophies.

75.92.text: if we built it, they will come.

78.98.text: that that was certainly not the case.

80.46.text: - It's not the case yeah, so we're still working on that.

85.11.text: I think generally speaking, the genomics industry

89.33.text: and the technology that's been developing over the last

92.03.text: decade has been moving extraordinarily quickly.

94.82.text: The cost per sequencing a base pair

97.66.text: is dropping much much faster than Moore's Law,

101.09.text: exponentially faster, in fact, and so it's really enabled

105.24.text: this technology to be applied in a clinical setting

108.38.text: now very rapidly, so I think at a meta level

110.84.text: that's been a surprise to all of us

112.65.text: in terms of how quickly that technology has developed.

115.12.text: But I think for us at the start-up,

119.06.text: and so the rate at which we've been growing,

121.40.text: we have a company value of GSD, which is Get Stuff Done.

127.49.text: It's just been a phenomenal experience

130.23.text: over the last several months to see how much a group

133.15.text: of really smart, like-minded, mission-driven folks

136.13.text: can get done, and so as an example,

138.53.text: we brought in our first wave of hires in March

141.38.text: and by August we had already started

143.94.text: enrolling in our first clinical trial,

146.75.text: which will end up enrolling over 10,000 subjects.

149.94.text: And just the pace at which that has happened

152.62.text: is pretty unprecedented in the oncology space.

156.17.text: And so that's been a very pleasing surprise for all of us.

159.79.text: - [Woman On Left] Great, so a good surprise.

163.20.text: - Yeah, I think for me, the big surprise was

167.35.text: when we were first starting this and kind of

169.89.text: working in the evenings, figuring things out,

172.43.text: I sort of naively thought that, oh,

177.82.text: we have two technical founders and one business co-founder,

181.65.text: and someone will give us an initial amount of money

184.90.text: to get out there and get going,

186.76.text: and then the later stage funding would be the hard part,

189.82.text: the first funding would be really easy.

192.07.text: And that turned out to not be the case at all.

194.19.text: No one really wanted to give us any money 'cause we had

196.42.text: no prototype, we just had an idea and had a decent story.

201.03.text: So what we had to do was end up getting government

204.21.text: funding to build our initial prototype,

206.79.text: and in general we've had to diversify

208.81.text: the streams in which we've raised money.

210.74.text: So we've also looked at philanthropy and family offices

213.73.text: and kind of to get us to the stage

216.03.text: where we would be attractive to venture funding

218.11.text: at a later point, we're still not there yet.

220.47.text: We're bringing in angel investors and that type of thing,

223.33.text: but we're not quite ready for the venture capital funding.

226.17.text: And so that has been the most surprising part,

228.04.text: you hear all these stories about, oh,

230.01.text: a couple students got their initial seed funding

232.82.text: right out of school and then could take off.

234.94.text: For a clean tech company, and doing hardware,

241.17.text: - So, I was surprised by how many people

244.80.text: will tell you that you can't do it.

247.72.text: When I started Bright, so, I wasn't fluent in Spanish,

251.10.text: I still am not, and our first market is Mexico.

253.74.text: So there were some things that just didn't make sense,

255.89.text: and I knew that, but I also was very surprised

258.47.text: that so many people said, that just doesn't make sense,

260.83.text: you can't start in a country you've never been to

263.22.text: that you have no connections to,

265.02.text: and you can't speak the language.

267.55.text: And it was like, the nos, and, what are you doing,

270.32.text: you're crazy, would come from everywhere.

272.41.text: I think there was maybe 5% of the people I talked to

275.21.text: that were really supportive, and like, this is a great idea.

278.22.text: But it's kind of like, I don't know if anyone,

280.93.text: who here has signed up for a race

283.15.text: that they thought was a crazy race,

285.32.text: but then because they signed up, they just did it?

288.32.text: That's how it works, and it's kind of the same

292.84.text: You kind of just have to sign up, make the leap,

295.85.text: and then on the opposite side of the coin,

298.09.text: I was surprised by how much you can

299.76.text: figure out if you just do that.

301.72.text: Actually, I flew to Mexico for the first time

306.29.text: and the power of the Stanford network,

308.21.text: I reached out to Stanford alumni in Mexico,

310.51.text: and someone I had never met, I ended up staying with,

313.38.text: and my flight was late, so I ended up

315.33.text: getting there at midnight, he was asleep.

317.15.text: It was a very awkward interaction when I was blowing up

319.06.text: the air mattress to sleep on his floor.

321.19.text: And that's, it's a crazy start,

323.25.text: but that was my first connection in Mexico,

325.51.text: and then it just grew from there.

327.39.text: And yeah, it was crazy and it didn't make any sense.

329.79.text: But kind of signing up for it is the most important step

332.71.text: that you can take, and you'll test your limits,

335.42.text: but you will succeed far more

337.30.text: than you think you're capable of,

339.17.text: and it will only happen if you sign up.
